pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.html:
@sloretz We removed Descriptor::QueryMsgTypesOfTopic(), so this is no longer being used (and neither is QueryMsgTypesOfTopic()).

Should we just remove these unused functions? We could keep them around in case we ever want to bring back Descriptor::QueryMsgTypesOfTopic(), but that might be kind of pointless.

I'm mostly indifferent, but leaning towards removing these.

content.html: Thanks for removing them in 3bee61b

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.html: I like the use of the test hook here to make this more strictly a unit test and not an integration test.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
Not that it matters for the test, but for anyone who might not know, you could use

```
const auto& topicMap = desc.TopicsToMsgTypesToId();
```

to avoid recreating a whole map.

Even though the return type of the function is a const-reference, if you use just plain `auto` the type will default to a non-const lvalue instead of a const-reference.
content.html:
Not that it matters for the test, but for anyone who might not know, you could use

const auto& topicMap = desc.TopicsToMsgTypesToId();

to avoid recreating a whole map.

Even though the return type of the function is a const-reference, if you use just plain auto the type will default to a non-const lvalue instead of a const-reference.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw: This dependency is not trivial as it is right now. I see that we're using `Time` and `Console`. Are these the only classes that we'll need for logging/playback? Are there any plans to depend only on the core part of Ignition Common?
content.html: This dependency is not trivial as it is right now. I see that we're using Time and Console. Are these the only classes that we'll need for logging/playback? Are there any plans to depend only on the core part of Ignition Common?

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
We still haven't componentized `ignition-common`, so we're stuck with it being all-or-nothing for right now. Once it's broken into components, we would only need the core part of the library.

While I like the `Time` and `Console` classes, I'm pretty sure we can get by with basic STL functionality (but @sloretz can feel free to correct me if I'm wrong).

I think we should at least make `ignition-common1` an optional dependency instead of required, like I mentioned [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/270/logging-part-2-inserting-messages-into-a/activity#comment-55613137).
content.html:
We still haven't componentized ignition-common, so we're stuck with it being all-or-nothing for right now. Once it's broken into components, we would only need the core part of the library.

While I like the Time and Console classes, I'm pretty sure we can get by with basic STL functionality (but @sloretz can feel free to correct me if I'm wrong).

I think we should at least make ignition-common1 an optional dependency instead of required, like I mentioned here.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
Time would be pretty easy to replace with `std::chrono::nanoseconds`. I think the way the tests are using `Filesystem` could be replaced using the technique in the second section on [this page of the sqlite3 docs](https://www.sqlite.org/inmemorydb.html).

`Console` verbosity was very helpful while writing command line part. It would be  a shame to lose it, but we could make do with `std::cout` and `std::cerr`.
content.html:
Time would be pretty easy to replace with std::chrono::nanoseconds. I think the way the tests are using Filesystem could be replaced using the technique in the second section on this page of the sqlite3 docs.

Console verbosity was very helpful while writing command line part. It would be a shame to lose it, but we could make do with std::cout and std::cerr.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
Yeah, I really like `Console`. I'd love to get a header-only implementation of it into the upcoming `ign-cmake` utilities, although it may be a bit tricky to make it header-only due to the static variables.

I think testing on actual files might have some value to it, although if we can rely on `sqlite3` to work equivalently on both types of databases (which I should hope is the case), then that alternative in-memory approach seems like a reasonable option.
content.html:
Yeah, I really like Console. I'd love to get a header-only implementation of it into the upcoming ign-cmake utilities, although it may be a bit tricky to make it header-only due to the static variables.

I think testing on actual files might have some value to it, although if we can rely on sqlite3 to work equivalently on both types of databases (which I should hope is the case), then that alternative in-memory approach seems like a reasonable option.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
Hypothetically, we could replace `Time` and `Console` with STL alternatives and then have the few integration tests depend on `ign-common` so they can use Filesystem (we would skip those tests if `ign-common` is unavailable).

I'm not saying this is a good idea, but it's an option, depending on how badly we want to minimize the dependency on `ign-common`.
content.html:
Hypothetically, we could replace Time and Console with STL alternatives and then have the few integration tests depend on ign-common so they can use Filesystem (we would skip those tests if ign-common is unavailable).

I'm not saying this is a good idea, but it's an option, depending on how badly we want to minimize the dependency on ign-common.

```
return this->dataPtr && this->dataPtr->db;
```

Was there any particular motivation for explicitly calling the implicit conversion operator here? It seems to work just fine by doing

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw: I don't remember. If the tests pass then +1 to implicitly calling it.
content.html: I don't remember. If the tests pass then +1 to implicitly calling it.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
Oh, I just realized that `*db` (which is a `raii_sqlite3::Database`) has an `operator bool()`. However, this is calling the `operator bool()` of the `std::shared_ptr` which is containing the `raii_sqlite3::Database`.

If it's possible to have a situation where a `Database` has been allocated but is not valid, then we might actually want to do:

```
return this->dataPtr && this->dataPtr->db && *(this->dataPtr->db);
```

That should give us the intended behavior, if I understand correctly.
content.html:
Oh, I just realized that *db (which is a raii_sqlite3::Database) has an operator bool(). However, this is calling the operator bool() of the std::shared_ptr which is containing the raii_sqlite3::Database.

If it's possible to have a situation where a Database has been allocated but is not valid, then we might actually want to do:

return this->dataPtr && this->dataPtr->db && *(this->dataPtr->db);

That should give us the intended behavior, if I understand correctly.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
We're trying to keep its use very limited for right now, because it's a big can of worms to spin off a replacement for the `ign-common` console.

At the moment, the only way to change verbosity level will be through the command line tool (although the command line tool won't be introduced until the 8th pull request in this sequence).

By keeping the entire implementation and interface for this feature private, we don't have to worry about maintaining it for users, and we can replace it at any time without worry.
content.html:
We're trying to keep its use very limited for right now, because it's a big can of worms to spin off a replacement for the ign-common console.

At the moment, the only way to change verbosity level will be through the command line tool (although the command line tool won't be introduced until the 8th pull request in this sequence).

By keeping the entire implementation and interface for this feature private, we don't have to worry about maintaining it for users, and we can replace it at any time without worry.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
I'm okay with that and it would work just fine, but since `Descriptor` is part of the `Log` API, I'd personally prefer to `#include` it in the `Log` header so it's readily available to users who want to get it.

Otherwise users will have to figure out that they need to explicitly include `Descriptor.hh` before they're able to use this `Log` function, and that can be irritating.
content.html:
I'm okay with that and it would work just fine, but since Descriptor is part of the Log API, I'd personally prefer to #include it in the Log header so it's readily available to users who want to get it.

Otherwise users will have to figure out that they need to explicitly include Descriptor.hh before they're able to use this Log function, and that can be irritating.

![coverage.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/og7EBq/images/4192661148-coverage.png)
content.html: Here's the code coverage report. Do you think we could improve Log.cc and raii-sqlite3.cc?

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
I think the coverage should be judged by the final pull request ([coverage here](https://codecov.io/bb/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/tree/4657f372f5aa0f3792388e1f22f43b2560d1f5fc)). In this PR the coverage in `Log.cc` and `raii-sqlite3.cc` looks bad because they are full of defensive checks that should never be triggered. The coverage of these two files cannot reasonably be increased. In the case of `Log.cc` it will look better after part 4 because additional makes the percentage of defensive code go down.

Edit: Part 4 also adds SQL statements that use parameters which tests a significant chunk of code in `Log.cc`.
content.html:
I think the coverage should be judged by the final pull request (coverage here). In this PR the coverage in Log.cc and raii-sqlite3.cc looks bad because they are full of defensive checks that should never be triggered. The coverage of these two files cannot reasonably be increased. In the case of Log.cc it will look better after part 4 because additional makes the percentage of defensive code go down.

Edit: Part 4 also adds SQL statements that use parameters which tests a significant chunk of code in Log.cc.

content.raw: I don't think it is possible. `_columns` is a map and the hash of `TopicKey` is made from the [name and type](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/270/logging-part-2-inserting-messages-into-a/diff#Llog/src/Descriptor.hhT82).
content.html: I don't think it is possible. _columns is a map and the hash of TopicKey is made from the name and type.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
Looking at the tests, I see the following pattern for constructing a `Descriptor`:

* Instantiate a `Descriptor` object.
* Populate a `TopicKeyMap` object.
* Call reset to populate `desc` with `topics`.

Would it be possible to simplify this pattern by offering a `Descriptor` constructor that accepts a `TopicKeyMap` object?

Also, is there any way of directly adding some entries to an existing descriptor without resetting entirely?
content.html:
Looking at the tests, I see the following pattern for constructing a Descriptor:

  • Instantiate a Descriptor object.
  • Populate a TopicKeyMap object.
  • Call reset to populate desc with topics.

Would it be possible to simplify this pattern by offering a Descriptor constructor that accepts a TopicKeyMap object?

Also, is there any way of directly adding some entries to an existing descriptor without resetting entirely?

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw: There isn't a way to directly add entries to the descriptor currently. It hasn't been optimized to do partial updates because it's pretty cheap and happens infrequently. It happens only once per topic it when recording, and only once total when playing back.
content.html: There isn't a way to directly add entries to the descriptor currently. It hasn't been optimized to do partial updates because it's pretty cheap and happens infrequently. It happens only once per topic it when recording, and only once total when playing back.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw:
`std::chrono::time_point` is attached to a clock, but there isn't an appropriate clock in the standard library. The necessary clock would be monotonic (like `steady_clock`) and use the Unix epoch (like `system_clock` most of the time). 

In part 5 `Recorder` [gets the delta](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/273/logging-part-5-record-ignition-transport/diff#Llog/src/Recorder.ccT101) between `steady_clock` and `system_clock` at startup. When it receives a message it gets the time from `steady_clock` and [adds the delta](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-transport/pull-requests/273/logging-part-5-record-ignition-transport/diff#Llog/src/Recorder.ccT138). The result is the time between messages is accurately recorded, and the relationship to wall time is close enough to be useful.
content.html:
std::chrono::time_point is attached to a clock, but there isn't an appropriate clock in the standard library. The necessary clock would be monotonic (like steady_clock) and use the Unix epoch (like system_clock most of the time).

In part 5 Recorder gets the delta between steady_clock and system_clock at startup. When it receives a message it gets the time from steady_clock and adds the delta. The result is the time between messages is accurately recorded, and the relationship to wall time is close enough to be useful.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw: What is the reason for not using a `steady_clock` directly? Do we care about timing in absolute terms? I know we care about timing relative to the start of the log at least.
content.html: What is the reason for not using a steady_clock directly? Do we care about timing in absolute terms? I know we care about timing relative to the start of the log at least.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw: For the purposes of playback a monotonic time is good enough. Time relative to UTC epoch is for someone querying messages via the `Log` class. They may have a log of some bad behavior at 3:30pm and want query around that time.
content.html: For the purposes of playback a monotonic time is good enough. Time relative to UTC epoch is for someone querying messages via the Log class. They may have a log of some bad behavior at 3:30pm and want query around that time.

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw: Returning `true` means everything is OK. It wasn't time to end the transaction so it didn't end it. The purpose of these two functions is to combine multiple insert statements into one transaction. The reason for doing that is here https://www.sqlite.org/faq.html#q19
content.html: Returning true means everything is OK. It wasn't time to end the transaction so it didn't end it. The purpose of these two functions is to combine multiple insert statements into one transaction. The reason for doing that is here https://www.sqlite.org/faq.html#q19

pullrequest.title: Logging Part 2: Inserting messages into a log file

content.raw: I guess my doubt is that if this function returns `true`, I don't really know whether the transaction ended or not, right?. The name of the function makes me think that if it returns `true` the transaction has been ended. I'm fine with it if you don't see any problems.
content.html: I guess my doubt is that if this function returns true, I don't really know whether the transaction ended or not, right?. The name of the function makes me think that if it returns true the transaction has been ended. I'm fine with it if you don't see any problems.
